title: Tutorial for R package kwb.default
text: Instead setting constant values function’s definition, can use calls getDefault() look current default values function’s arguments call function without arguments set. , instead defining function hello1() constant default values "Mona" "Lisa" formal arguments firstName lastName, respectively: define function assigning calls getDefault() default values, like : set default values separately setDefault(): functions now behave way: However, hello2() can easily change default values without update function’s definition, just calling setDefault() : call function now without arguments, new defaults used: Note setDefault() raise error function specified exist
code: hello1 <- function (   firstName = "Mona",    lastName = "Lisa" )  {   cat(paste0("Hello ", firstName, " ", lastName, "!\n")) } hello2 <- function (   firstName = getDefault("hello2", "firstName"),   lastName = getDefault("hello2", "lastName") )  {   cat(paste0("Hello ", firstName, " ", lastName, "!\n")) } setDefault("hello2", firstName = "Mona", lastName = "Lisa") hello1() ## Hello Mona Lisa! hello2() ## Hello Mona Lisa! setDefault("hello2", firstName = "Don", lastName = "Quichote") hello2() ## Hello Don Quichote! tryCatch(setDefault("hello", firstName = "Peter")) ## Error in get(parts[1]) : object 'hello' not found ## Error: 'hello' does not seem to be a function!

title: Get the default value that is defined for a function's argument — getDefault
code: # Once you have defined a function... hello <- function(firstName = getDefault("hello", "firstName")) {   cat("Hello", firstName, "\n") }  # ... you can define the default value for its arguments... setDefault("hello", firstName = "Peter") #> Error in get(parts[1]) : object 'hello' not found #> Error: 'hello' does not seem to be a function!  # ... and read it back with getDefault()... getDefault("hello", "firstName") #> Error in get(parts[1]) : object 'hello' not found #> There are no defaults for function 'hello' defined! Use setDefault('hello', firstName = ...) to set a default value. Also, 'hello' does not seem to be a function!  Returning the default value:  #> NULL

title: Define the default value for a function's argument — setDefault
code: if (FALSE) {  # This will lead to an error if funtion "hello" is not defined setDefault("hello", firstName = "Peter")  # Define the function and use getDefault instead of a constant default value hello <- function(   firstName = getDefault("hello", "firstName"),   lastName = getDefault("hello", "lastName") ) {   cat(paste0("Hello ", firstName, " ", lastName, "!\n") ) }  # Now you can define the argument defaults setDefault("hello", firstName = "Don", lastName = "Quichote")  # If you call the function without arguments, the defaults are used hello()  # You can now change the defaults without changing the function definition setDefault("hello", firstName = "Mona", lastName = "Lisa")  hello() }
